Dave -

Thanks for the suggestion; that does seem a reasonable way of 
doing things, and should work for what we need.  (Also, it occurs 
to me that it might be useful to have the lightweight objects 
carry around the handle to their corresponding heavyweight 
object, so I can use the heavyweight in subfunctions without 
having to explicitly pass it.)

I can imagine that it would be most convenient to have Cantera's 
own classes set up so that I can define something like "f = air" 
and then define "g = copy(f)", and have it create an f and g that 
have individual state data but share the same reaction data.  
However, this is certainly something that can be approximated 
quite closely on the user end by defining lightweight structures 
as you suggest, so it certainly isn't something I'd consider to be 
either necessary or urgent.

It also occurs to me that it might be worth including something 
illustrating the creation of lightweight objects to handle multiple 
states and copying thereof in the tutorials.  Would you consider 
that worth including if I were to write such a thing?

- Brooks


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Brooks -
> 
> I would recommend that you consider changing your code to avoid making  
> multiple copies of class Solution objects. The reason is that these are  
> "heavyweights" - each one contains all reaction mechanism data.  So an  
> alternative would be to create a single heavyweight object, and many  
> "lightweight" ones that are pure Matlab objects or structures that just  
> hold state information (temperature, density or pressure, + mass  
> fractions). Then pass the lightweight objects to your functions, to set  
> the initial state for a calculation. Something like this:
[...]
